abstract: Cattle treated with chemicals to control parasites can fecally excrete residues that have the potential to adversely affect local assemblages of dung beetles (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae). Using 200-m transects and dung-baited pitfall traps, we compared the dung beetle communities on 19 cattle farms in Maryland, USA where pests and/or parasites were controlled with chemicals (CU, n = 9 farms) or where no chemicals were used (NCU, n = 10 farms). Traps were baited once a month with fresh cattle dung from each location. We collected a total of 31 species comprising 12,380 dung beetle specimens. The five most abundant species, Onthophagus taurus (Schreber), Onthophagus pennsylvanicus Harold, Onthophagus hecate (Panzer), Blackburneus stercorosus (Melsheimer), and Labarrus pseudolividus (Balthasar), accounted for 85% of the total individuals sampled. No difference was found when comparing total abundances of dung beetles sampled from NCU and CU farms. There was, however, a consistent significant effect of month across multiple dominant species. Using Random Forests analyses, we determined site location, soil type, and chemical lethality as additional important predictor variables affecting dung beetle abundances on Maryland farms. Present-day management practices implement a broad spectrum of chemical usage. Our work examines this variability to facilitate the understanding of factors currently affecting the biodiversity and abundance of beneficial dung beetles. ABSTRACT
Muslim women experience gendered Islamophobia because their Muslim identity is often more visible and comes to symbolize their culture. Experiencing discrimination can cause stress and negative mental health outcomes. However, Muslim identity can also be a source of coping, and the Muslim community can be a source of support in the face of Islamophobia. We hypothesized that openness about identity within the Muslim community may differ based on gender and that experiences of discrimination would be associated with a desire to hide one’s Muslim identity in public for women but not for men. Seventy-three Muslim college students were recruited through snowball sampling in a cross-sectional survey in North America. Mean differences and correlational patterns were compared between women (n = 35) and men (n = 30). Correlational and regression analyses revealed that for women but not men, discrimination was correlated with hiding one’s Muslim identity in public. Microaggressions and offence at Trump’s proposed travel ban were related to openness with other Muslims for women only. Women were more offended than men by Trump’s statement but only after President Trump took office. Intersectionality needs to be unpacked to better understand the multidimensional nature of gendered Islamophobia and racist policy actions.

KEYWORDS: Gendered Islamophobia, Muslim women, religious identity, intersectionality, travel ban

We investigated ant species richness and abundance of the maritime forest and dune habitats of Assateague Island, a barrier island off the coasts of Maryland and Virginia. We paired 5 transects of 100 m in forest habitats with 5 transects in dune and grassland habitats, with pitfall traps set every 10 m along each transect. During a 5-month period (May–September), we collected 26 species of ants, including 9 that had not been previously recorded on the island and 2 that had never been recorded east of Maryland's Chesapeake Bay. We provide evidence for forest habitats supporting higher species richness and make suggestions for future research.

## Abstract
Ethics are principles which provide a framework for making decisions that best reflect a set of values. Cataloging carries power, so ethical decision-making is crucial. Because cataloging requires decision-making in areas that differ from other library work, cataloging ethics are a distinct subset of library ethics. Cataloging ethics draw on the primary values of serving the needs of users and providing access to materials. Cataloging ethics are not new, but they have received increased attention since the 1970s. Major current issues in cataloging ethics include the creation of a code of ethics; ongoing debate on the appropriate role of neutrality in cataloging misleading materials and in subject heading lists and classification schemes; how and to what degree considerations of privacy and self-determination should shape authority work; and whether or not our current cataloging codes are sufficiently user-focused.

**Abstract**  
Verbal coercion experience is common among college women and has sometimes been associated with lower self-esteem. The current study examined self-esteem based on the two verbal coercion items included in the latest version of the most popular measure of sexual victimization experience, the Sexual Experiences Survey-Short Form Victimization (SES-SFV; Koss et al., 2007). One item includes verbal tactics categorized as “threat” and the other item includes verbal tactics categorized as “criticism.” Undergraduate women (n = 479) completed the Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale and the SES-SFV. Results showed that women who experienced criticism reported lower self-esteem than those who did not experience criticism. However, threat experience was not significantly related to women’s self-esteem. Findings support Koss et al.’s suggestion that criticism tactics are more negative than threat tactics, and imply that self-esteem may be negatively associated with some sexually coercive verbal tactics but not associated with others. Future researchers should pay careful attention to operational definitions of verbal coercion.

There is a need for more research on the experiences of affirming parents of pre-adolescent transgender and gender non-conforming (TGNC) children. This study explores how parents conceptualized advocacy roles. Eleven parents of TGNC children age 13 and under completed semi-structured phone interviews. Ten parents considered themselves advocates, with digital advocacy being the most common. Advocacy motivations centered around parental concerns. This study investigates the impact of mobile money (MM) on SMEs' resilience and the associated business outcome in developing countries amid Covid-19. Despite the potential of MM to improve SMEs' resilience, little evidence has been documented. Using Enterprise Survey data in Zambia, we show that SMEs are more likely than large firms to experience catastrophic sales decline, reflecting their inherent vulnerability. Further analysis reveals that this unfavorable effect can be effectively counteracted when SMEs incorporate MM into daily business. An important policy implication is that the use of digital technologies should be a key element of policy responses to Covid-19.

The conflict between humans and elephants is common wherever they coexist, causing significant loss of crops, property and even human life (Kiffner et al., 2021). Some methods, such as the use of beehives, chili fences and electric fences, seem to reduce, but not eliminate, human/elephant conflict and property loss (Karidozo et al., 2006). However, these methods require permanent infrastructure and are difficult to deploy quickly. As with most human/wildlife conflict, it is individual elephants, not the species as a whole, that are responsible for this conflict. Elephants have large home ranges, and these individuals can shift the locus of their activity from one site to another. When conflict occurs, the most common solution is to kill the elephant (Karidozo & Osborn, 2015), even though both species of African (Loxodonta africana) and Asian (Elephas maximus) elephants are currently endangered. Here we present a case study of an alternate method to killing, disruptive darting, that can be deployed quickly on elephants visiting a location where they are not desired, with obvious ethical and conservation benefits.

The subject of this study is a male elephant ~35 years old, who carries a GPS collar as part of a larger study. His home range includes the town of Victoria Falls, Zimbabwe, a popular tourist destination. Located within Victoria Falls National Park, the town’s tourism areas and residential properties connect directly to the surrounding wildlife areas. Therefore, it is common to observe wildlife traveling close to humans and their properties – sometimes even walking downtown during the daylight.

In July 2018, our subject began to feed on trees near the Victoria Falls Baobab Elementary School, which caused concerns when children were playing in the school yard. The school contacted the Zimbabwe Parks & Wildlife Management Authority (ZimParks), requesting he be ‘removed’ from their property. In an effort to keep the bull alive, and the children safe, ZimParks allowed us to anesthetize the animal and apply concentrated chili wax (>150000 Scoville units) on sensitive parts of his body (avoiding the eyes). Based on human reactions to the wax, this would have caused non-lethal, temporary but intense discomfort, lasting 45–90 minutes. The bull approached within 375 meters of the school buildings on three consecutive days immediately before the application of the wax, spending most of each day there. After application he immediately left and stayed away from the area around the school for 1 year and 2 months, never entering the school yard nor approaching closer than 375 meters. After this period of complete avoidance, he came within 375 meters of the school only three times, in September and October 2020. These visits were always during the night when no humans were present. This nocturnal behavior is consistent with other studies about elephants avoiding humans. In the 2 years after the mitigation, he has yet to approach within 250 meters of the school.

However, while he largely avoided the location of the mitigation event for over 2 years, and still seems to be avoiding humans in that area by visiting only at night, he did not generalize this avoidance to all humans, since he still visited other parts of the town, when people were present, during this period.

Thus, this disruptive darting, while having notable implementation costs in terms of personnel and materials, produced a long-term effect that benefits the conservation of elephants and reduces human–elephant conflict. This may make the costs comparable to installing and maintaining infrastructure solutions like bee hives or fencing over a comparable period. Disruptive darting can be deployed quickly, and it keeps alive endangered elephants that would otherwise be killed. There is also the potential, yet to be explored, that an elephant initially treated with disruptive darting may associate the smell of capsicum with the experience, and thus be deterred by less invasive and less expensive mitigation methods, such as burning chili-infused dung bricks.

In addition to its practical benefits, the method described here has implications for the study of the cognitive behavior of elephants. Elephants are known to have excellent spatial memory and the ability to discriminate between humans whom they perceive as a threat and those whom they perceive as safe. Our study is consistent with these findings, in that the elephant seemed to associate the unpleasant event with a specific location, and perhaps with people at that location, rather than people in general. Further investigation of this technique may provide insight into the cognitive processes of an intelligent non-human animal.

This study's objective is to examine the role of resilience in the dynamic between academic burnout and psychological distress using a sample of US undergraduate accounting majors. It extends prior research—that is, García-Izquierdo et al. (2018), who examine these relationships using a sample of Spanish nursing students. For this study, a survey instrument was concurrently administered to 443 accounting majors at four geographically dispersed universities. Two alternative models are tested. The first model positions resilience as an exogenous predictor, and dimensions of academic burnout antecedent to psychological distress. The results indicate a significant negative association between resilience, psychological distress, and each of the three academic burnout dimensions. In addition, emotional exhaustion and academic inefficacy have a significant positive association with psychological distress. The alternative model positions psychological distress antecedent to each of the academic burnout dimensions. The results indicate that resilience has a significant negative association with psychological distress, cynicism, and academic inefficacy, but not emotional exhaustion. Moreover, psychological distress has significant positive associations with each academic burnout dimension. In the alternative model specification, resilience is also found to moderate the association between psychological distress and academic inefficacy. This single moderating effect notwithstanding, the findings suggest that the primary role of resilience is that of a compensatory mechanism by acting as an independent exogenous predictor of distress and burnout.

Buchwald–Hartwig Amination, High-Throughput Experimentation, and Process Chemistry: An Introduction via Undergraduate Laboratory Experimentation

This three-part laboratory experiment investigates key aspects of the Buchwald–Hartwig amination cross-coupling reaction through guided-inquiry learning strategies. The first part of this experiment utilizes high-throughput experimentation techniques to reinforce, explore, and extend fundamental concepts that are represented in the classroom, including the use of air-free Schlenk techniques and heteronuclear NMR analysis. The second component challenges students to evaluate their results to design, set up, and perform a preparative-scale Buchwald–Hartwig amination. Finally, students purify and isolate their products using column chromatography allowing them to fully characterize their target molecules through a variety of analytical techniques. This experiment represents one of the final experiments performed in the fourth-year undergraduate chemistry curriculum and serves as a capstone learning experience for students.

This paper explores how trust in formal information sources (government and media) and informal information sources (interpersonal) about COVID-19 influences compliance with preventive measures. This cross-sectional study uses convenience sampling of 478 adult participants. Data analyses using structural equation modeling with multigroup comparisons examine hypothesized relationships between trust in information sources and preventative behaviors and social distancing. Results suggest that understanding of COVID-19 causes is related to trust in formal information sources, but not to trust in informal information. Self-efficacy for prevention is related to trust in informal information sources, but not to trust in formal information sources. Worry about contracting COVID-19 is related to trust in formal information sources, but not to informal ones. Engaging in preventive measures is linked to both self-efficacy for prevention and worry, while social distancing was related only to worry. These findings have important implications for public health policy guidelines centered on clear and truthful media messages. This study was conducted to examine the effect of two resistance training models on arterial stiffness in females.

## Abstract
Prior research links adaptive humor styles (affiliative and self-enhancing) with enhanced psychological well-being and maladaptive humor styles (aggressive and self-defeating) with worse psychological well-being, primarily through humor styles’ influence on individuals’ social interactions and efforts to positively reframe stressors. The present study examined the unique relation of each humor style with psychological well-being with a focus on understanding mechanisms of adjustment under highly stressful conditions. Ninety-nine parents of children with disabilities were surveyed at the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States in March 2020, and 79 parents completed follow-up surveys in July 2020. As predicted, at T1, self-enhancing humor was associated with less psychological distress and greater family satisfaction, self-defeating humor was associated with greater distress, and aggressive humor was associated with lower family satisfaction. Moreover, affiliative humor predicted decreased psychological distress over time, whereas self-defeating humor predicted increased psychological distress and decreased family satisfaction over time. Relations were largely mediated by caregiver positive reappraisal, family efforts to reframe daily disability-related challenges, and negative social interactions. Future research should further examine the influence of caregiver humor styles on family dynamics, family reframing norms, and caregiving efficacy.

## Introduction
Research on Martin et al.’s (2003) adaptive and maladaptive humor styles has burgeoned in recent years. Adaptive styles use positive, benign humor to connect with others by means of funny comments or anecdotes (affiliative humor), or to bolster the self by noting amusing or ironic aspects of daily events (self-enhancing humor). By contrast, maladaptive styles use injurious or sarcastic humor to insult others and thereby elevate the self (aggressive humor) or to disparage the self as a means of connecting with or gaining attention from others (self-defeating humor; see Martin (2007), for a review). Recent work has focused on the role of humor styles in coping with real-life stressors. Such work is essential to the conceptualization of these constructs: If we are to continue labeling humor styles as “adaptive” and “maladaptive,” we must examine how these concepts operate under conditions that require some sort of adaptation.

Emerging evidence suggests that the adaptive humor styles do indeed facilitate adjustment to stressors outside of the laboratory, including coping with police work (Kerkkanen et al., 2004), university academics (Fritz, 2020a), chronic pain (Ramirez-Meastra et al., 2020), infertility (Ostovar et al., 2020), and terrorist attacks (Fritz et al., 2017). By contrast, the maladaptive humor styles interfere with adjustment to these same stressors, with a particularly strong pattern of evidence demonstrating that self-defeating humor predicts worse psychological and physical adaptation to stressors over time (Fritz, 2020b; Schneider et al., 2018).

Parents of children with disabilities live under chronically stressful conditions (Isa et al., 2016; Neely-Barnes & Dia, 2008). A recent review of the literature on cerebral palsy and family stress concluded that parents of children with disabilities report greater stress and worse mental and physical health than parents of typically developing children (Fritz & Sewell-Roberts, 2018). A variety of social, emotional, and health behavior factors explain this disparity in well-being. However, it is important to note that not all parents of children with disabilities fare poorly: Considerable variability in well-being exists even among those parenting children with severe disabilities. Parent financial resources, social support, self-efficacy, and coping strategies all help to explain why some parent-caregivers thrive while others struggle (Fritz & Sewell-Roberts, 2018).

Three studies to date have examined the coping strategy of humor use among parents of children with disabilities and found that the positive aspects of humor use are linked with enhanced caregiver well-being and family functioning (Fritz, 2020b; Rieger & McGrail, 2013, 2015). The present study aims to extend prior work by examining the role of humor styles in adapting to a potentially more stressful situation than those of past studies: Caregiving for a child with a disability during a global pandemic.

## Goals
To summarize, the goals of the present study were (1) to replicate the relations of humor styles with well-being among individuals coping with significant chronic stress—the parents of children with disabilities during a global pandemic, (2) to extend past work on the relation of humor styles with well-being among parent-caregivers by controlling for shared variance among humor styles and by obtaining a larger T2 sample, (3) to extend prior work by examining the effects of humor styles on family satisfaction, (4) to replicate past research showing that caregivers’ positive reappraisal mediates relations of humor styles with psychological well-being and to extend this concept to two new family-level reappraisal coping constructs created for this study, positive reframing of daily disability-related challenges and positive reframing of disability-related emergencies, and (5) to replicate past research showing that social interactions mediate relations of humor styles with well-being.

## Keywords
Caregiving, disability, parents of children with disabilities, humor styles, reframing, cognitive reappraisal, COVID-19

Abstract
Statistics is an important component of the knowledge base for health care professionals. In this essay, it is argued that statistical knowledge for teaching (SKT) should be considered an important component of their preparation as well. Health care professionals often must help others understand the statistical basis for recommendations they make. A COVID-19 press briefing is used to illustrate the need for SKT when making high-stakes recommendations related to public health. It is conjectured that efforts to educate the public during the press briefing would have been enhanced if the presenters had deeper knowledge of the general public’s common statistical thinking patterns, the typical statistics curriculum experienced by members of their audience, and contemporary tools for teaching statistics. The importance of such knowledge to support smaller-scale individual interactions is also discussed. A call for SKT-centered partnerships between educational researchers and medical researchers is made; such partnerships could be mutually beneficial to the development of both fields and to society at large.

Keywords: Dynamic statistics software, Medical research, Pedagogical content knowledge, Statistical knowledge for teaching, Statistical thinking

This article is part of the following collections: Teaching Data Science and Statistics and the COVID-19 Pandemic

1. Introduction
It is widely accepted that statistics is an important part of the knowledge base for those in the health professions (e.g., World Federation for Medical Education, 2015; Oster and Enders, 2018). Statistical knowledge allows health care professionals to understand research literature and conduct their own studies. Although the specific statistical concepts to be addressed and appropriate pedagogical approaches are at times under-specified in standards for medical education (Hayat, 2014), few would argue against requiring those entering the health professions to study statistics.

This essay focuses on a different type of knowledge that health care professionals should have: statistical knowledge for teaching (SKT). SKT is not equivalent to statistical knowledge. Concisely stated, SKT is knowledge that allows one to make statistics comprehensible to others (Groth, 2013). Health care professionals need to help people make evidence-based decisions about courses of action for preserving and improving their well-being (Nelson et al., 2002), though their ability and confidence to do so are sometimes questionable (Rao, 2008). Doctors and nurses frequently make data-based recommendations during private interactions with individuals; government officials charged with preserving public health are sometimes called upon to do so on a large scale in public. This educational responsibility was especially visible during the COVID-19 pandemic. This essay argues that having statistical knowledge alone is not sufficient to teach the public about the evidential basis for recommended health practices. It is also important to have knowledge of effective teaching practices that account for how people generally interpret statistics.

The essay begins with a brief description of the nature of SKT and how it overlaps, with yet differs from, from statistical and mathematical knowledge. Then, the notion of SKT is used to reflect upon a widely viewed press briefing in which two prominent health care professionals in the United States tried to explain the statistical basis for COVID-19 mitigation measures and treatments at a critical point in the pandemic timeline. The major statistical concepts they dealt with during the press briefing are discussed, and conjectures about how their attempt to educate the public may have been enhanced by deeper SKT are made. Broader implications about the need for SKT among health care professionals around the world and strategies for meeting the need are then considered.

2. The Nature of SKT
SKT encompasses more than just statistics subject matter knowledge; it also includes pedagogical content knowledge (Groth, 2013). Shulman (1987) characterized pedagogical content knowledge as the “special amalgam of content and pedagogy that is uniquely the province of teachers, their own special form of professional understanding” (p. 8). Having subject matter expertise alone does not make one an effective teacher; good statisticians may or may not have pedagogical skill. Pedagogical content knowledge has been studied extensively within the context of teachers in conventional classroom settings (Depaepe, Verschaffel, and Kelchtermans, 2013); the present article extends the consideration of pedagogical content knowledge to health care professionals charged with making evidence-based recommendations to the public.

Hill, Ball, and Schilling (2008) discussed three essential components of pedagogical content knowledge: knowledge of content and students, knowledge of content and teaching, and curriculum knowledge. These three components have been used widely in research on SKT (Langrall et al., 2017). Knowledge of content and students involves knowing how individuals commonly understand, and misunderstand, statistics content. Such knowledge supports knowledge of content and teaching, which allows for the selection of pedagogical strategies that leverage existing student understandings and address their common misunderstandings. A third component of pedagogical content knowledge, curriculum knowledge, provides understanding of the broad frameworks and learning progressions that generally undergird the teaching of statistics.

Along with being more than just statistical subject matter knowledge, SKT is also more than just mathematical knowledge. Undoubtedly, a great deal of mathematical knowledge is needed to teach statistics. However, considerable amounts of nonmathematical knowledge are needed as well. For example, those who teach statistics must know how to distinguish between deterministic and stochastic questions, construct surveys, design studies, and interpret results in context (Groth, 2007). Mathematical knowledge is necessary, but not sufficient, for such tasks. Many statistical tasks are highly context-dependent and not reducible to deterministic algorithms and conclusions. At its core, statistics is the study of variation and uncertainty. This stands in contrast to mathematics, in which deductive reasoning can lead to definitive proofs. Mathematical tools are helpful for statistical tasks, yet we cannot expect them to produce conclusions as certain as those of mathematical proofs in most statistical contexts. Reconciling certainty in mathematics with uncertainty in statistics is a nontrivial task. Knowing how to help the public distinguish between statistical and mathematical conclusions during a time of anxiety such as the COVID-19 pandemic is especially challenging, as people naturally seek unequivocal answers to questions that cannot be answered with complete certainty.

3. SKT in the Context of a COVID-19 Press Briefing
In the United States, at the outset of the pandemic, Dr. Deborah Birx and Dr. Anthony Fauci were charged with explaining the basis for government-led COVID-19 mitigation and efforts to develop treatments and vaccines. On March 31, 2020, the two doctors employed statistical tools and arguments during a press briefing to do so. The press briefing came at a critical time, as the United States had recorded just a small percentage of its eventual deaths from the virus (approximately 4000 of what would grow to be over 250,000), and audiences for the daily briefings from the White House were averaging approximately 8 million viewers (Grynbaum, 2020). A primary goal of the briefing was to argue in favor of extending existing mitigation measures, which included stay-at-home orders, business closures, and maintaining social distance in public. Video of the press briefing was posted online afterward (e.g., https://www.c-span.org/video/?470841-1/white-house-warns-upcoming-painful-weeks&live=). Quotes in this essay were drawn from the government video transcript (available from https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefings-statements/remarks-president-trump-vice-president-pence-members-coronavirus-task-force-press-briefing-15/). The statistical subject matter of the press briefing included models, disaggregation of data, and experimental study design. Next, a summary of how Drs. Birx and Fauci dealt with each of these statistical ideas during the press briefing is given, followed by conjectures about how deeper SKT related to the three main statistical ideas may have enhanced their efforts to teach the public.

3.1 Press Briefing Introductory Presentation Summary
Dr. Birx began her portion of the press briefing by projecting the slide shown in Figure 1. Two curves appeared on the slide: one to illustrate the spread of COVID-19 without mitigation measures, and another to illustrate its spread with mitigation measures fully in place. She explained that the curves were based on modeling done by “five or six international and domestic modelers from Harvard, from Columbia, from Northeastern, from Imperial who helped us tremendously.” In reference to the curve on the far left in Figure 1, Dr. Birx stated, “In their estimates, they had between 1.5 million and 2.2 million people in the United States succumbing to this virus without mitigation.” She explained that the curve on the far right showed projected deaths if mitigation measures such as social distancing and hand-washing were fully implemented, saying, “what an extraordinary thing this could be if every American followed these, and it takes us to that stippled mountain that’s much lower—a hill, actually—down to 100,000 to 200,000 deaths, which is still way too much.”

Next, Dr. Birx projected the slide shown in Figure 2 and said it was from the work of a modeler at the University of Washington who took hospital need data from around the world into account. She explained that the graph depicted what would be possible with full implementation of the government’s mitigation measures, and that the model was being continuously updated each day by using new data. Dr. Birx further argued for full implementation of the recommended mitigation measures by showing a third slide with a graph (Figure 3). She used the third slide to argue that states with strong mitigation measures in place were more successful containing the disease, stating,

It was just a month ago when they started to have the issues in Washington State, but they brought together their communities and their health providers, and they put in strong mitigation methods and testing. And you can see what the result in Washington State and California is. But without the continuation for the next 30 days, anything could change.

She then displayed the slide shown in Figure 4 with data from all 50 states and the District of Columbia. The slide illustrated the scope of the problem in New York and New Jersey relative to other areas. Dr. Birx showed these data to encourage community-by-community mitigation to prevent spikes in cases in other states.

Dr. Birx ended the formal presentation portion of the press briefing by showing and discussing the slide in Figure 5. It was meant to further support her contention that mitigation measures should be fully implemented. Dr. Birx stated,

So this is what gives us a lot of hope. This is the case finding in Italy. And you can see that they’re beginning to turn the corner in new cases. They’re entering their fourth week of full mitigation and showing what is possible when we work together as a community, as a country, to change the course of this pandemic together.

Dr. Birx closed her portion of the presentation by asking the audience to continue existing mitigation measures for an additional 30 days. Dr. Fauci then came to the microphone to support her request. He warned the audience that the effects of mitigation might not be apparent immediately, and to not be discouraged if cases continued to rise in the short term. He finished his formal comments by stating the following about the government’s recommended mitigation measures:

It’s inconvenient from a societal standpoint, from an economic standpoint to go through this, but this is going to be the answer to our problems. So let’s all pull together and make sure, as we look forward to the next 30 days, we do it with all the intensity and force that we can.

After the formal presentation portion of the press briefing, Dr. Birx and Dr. Fauci responded to questions from reporters in attendance. Several questions and responses are incorporated in the next three subsections, because they help reveal how statistical ideas and claims included in the formal presentation portion of the press briefing were interpreted by the audience.

3.2 SKT and Statistical Models
During the question-and-answer portion of the press briefing, reporters asked about the model projections Dr. Birx had provided (Figure 1). One reporter began this line of questioning by asking, “Just to be clear, what is the projected death toll, should the people be reasonably good at following these mitigation measures?” Dr. Birx responded,

So, of course, this is a projection, and it’s a projection based on using very much what’s happened in Italy and then looking at all the models. And so, as you saw on that slide, that was our real number—that 100,000 to 200,000. And we think that that is the range. We really believe and hope every day that we can do a lot better than that—because that’s not assuming 100 percent of every American does everything that they’re supposed to be doing. But I think that’s possible.

Dr. Fauci added, “The modeling that Dr. Birx showed predicts that number that you saw—we don’t accept that number that that’s what’s going to be; we’re going to be doing everything we can to get it even significantly below that.” Later in the press briefing, questions about how model outputs would change in response to different inputs reemerged. Additional reporter questions of this type included:

- What do the models suggest is on the low end if you have full mitigation?
- If 100,000 is the number with full mitigation, how do you push it lower?
- If we had started these practices sooner, could these models be different right now?

The persistence of these types of questions throughout the press briefing suggests that a different strategy for teaching the relationship between model inputs and outputs would have been desirable. One strategy for teaching the relationship between model inputs and outputs would be to use dynamic, rather than static, graphical representations during the briefing. The emergence of dynamic representations can be considered one of the major developments in statistics pedagogy over the past two decades and an important part of the knowledge base for teaching the subject (Lee and Hollebrands, 2011). Rather than limiting graphical representations to the extreme cases of no mitigation and full mitigation (as in Figure 1), a dynamic graph would allow one to see how varying degrees of mitigation might change outcomes. Sliders assigned to parameters could be introduced to allow one to adjust inputs and observe the results. Users of the dynamic representation could then explore answers to questions like those that reporters posed about the impact of timing and extent of mitigation rather than having to rely upon just the two extreme ends of a continuum represented in static graphs (Figure 1). Knowing the educational possibilities of dynamic representations falls within the knowledge of content and teaching aspect of SKT.

As individuals interact with statistical models, it is important for them to know that such models are subject to change based on new data, conditions, and assumptions. Dr. Fauci acknowledged this during the press briefing, stating, “I know my modeling colleagues are going to not be happy with me, but models are as good as the assumptions you put into them, and as we get more data, then you put it in and that might change.” Although the comment rightly acknowledges degrees of uncertainty inherent in statistical models, it also indicates hesitation to question modelers’ authority and conclusions. Dr. Birx’s remarks earlier in the press briefing also contained several appeals to authority, as she named several prestigious institutions involved in the modeling process. It is generally not a sound teaching strategy to rely heavily on appeal to authority, because doing so can encourage passive consumption when active reflection is needed (Amit and Fried, 2005). Furthermore, it creates a perception that there are deterministic principles governing a phenomenon involving some uncertainty and variability. An important aspect of knowledge of content and students is to know that human beings have a tendency to favor deterministic explanations when stochastic ones are more appropriate (Rossman, 2008). Knowing this can help one anticipate the need to avoid framing stochastic situations deterministically.

An alternative to relying on appeal to authority would be to make the earlier-suggested dynamic model representation available online to the public, keep it up-to-date in terms of the newest available data, and encourage them to check it periodically to see how answers to their questions about mitigation have changed as more data became available. As answers to questions inevitably change in light of new data, the stochastic nature of the situation can become more apparent. This sort of continuous online interaction could foster a more authentic view of the degrees of variability, uncertainty, and predictability in the work of statistical modeling. Another potential benefit of such an approach would be allowing the public to see how their own actions may contribute to changes in the data upon which the model is based, therefore addressing the primary goal of the press briefing. This sort of arrangement could shift an appropriate amount of agency to the public to make projections and influence outcomes. Similar techniques have already been used to help television viewers engage with election data and make predictions. For example, many television networks use dynamic maps during elections to quickly zoom in on data from individual congressional districts and run “what-if” results scenarios based on changes in electoral vote inputs. Viewers are often invited to interact with the representation themselves online (e.g., https://www.cnn.com/election/2020/electoral-college-interactive-maps). Such techniques provide a glimpse at what may be possible for dynamic statistical model representations on television and online.

Although it is somewhat intuitive to expect that various inputs will produce different outputs as one interacts with a dynamic representation, understanding reasons why the same input may produce different outputs in a statistical model is more complicated. For example, Figure 2 shows a wide band to characterize uncertainty inherent in a model. Most inputs along the horizontal axis correspond to not just a single output, but a range of probable ones. Interactions during the press briefing do little to reveal how the audience interpreted the band of uncertainty in Figure 2, but it seems reasonable to conjecture that few considered statistical variability as an underlying factor. Individuals tend to cite contextual, rather than statistical, sources when prompted to explain sources of uncertainty in predictions (Henriques and Oliveira, 2016). Qualitative explanations for contextual sources of uncertainty are likely to emerge before reasoning that leads to quantification of statistical variability (Manor, Ben-Zvi, and Aridor, 2014). Thorough understanding of statistical variability and its quantification can be difficult to attain even for undergraduates who have taken statistics and/or are preparing to teach it (Lovett and Lee, 2018).

It is extremely challenging to address gaps in understanding of statistical variability during a brief interaction. Perhaps the most viable way to help the public develop better understanding of statistical variation is to invest more time on repeated sampling and informal inference activities in schools (Pratt and Ainley, 2008). Of course, this would require finding additional instructional time in perpetually crowded curricula, but doing so could improve individuals’ abilities to interpret model elements related to uncertainty such as the band shown in Figure 2. Health care professionals who partner with educators in developing such curricula would be in position to briefly remind the public of their experiences in school when helping them understand statistical variability in the context of health recommendations. Difficulties understanding statistical variability that persist even among those who have experienced enhanced curricula could be documented and used to continuously refine the curricula. Such ongoing interactions between health care professionals and curriculum developers could enhance the SKT of both groups.

3.3 SKT and Disaggregation and Contextualization of Data
The projected death toll of 100,000 or more in the slides displayed in Figures 1 and 2 led to a discussion about how individual state data might contribute to the total. During the question-and-answer portion of the briefing, the following exchange occurred:

Reporter: Can the country handle that in such a short period of time, within a couple of months? Fifty thousand a month (referring to projection of 100,000 deaths shown in Figure 1).

Dr. Fauci: You know, it will be difficult. I mean, no one is denying the fact that we are going through a very, very difficult time right now. I mean, we’re seeing what’s happening in New York. That is really, really tough. And if you extrapolate that to the nation, that will be really tough. But that’s what it is, Jim, and we’re going to have to be prepared for that.

Dr. Birx: Yeah, I think because the model—that model that was from IHME (Figure 2)—that’s based and heavily ladened by the data that has come in from New York and New Jersey and Connecticut. So, you know, that can skew to a higher peak and more significant mortality. If all of the other states are able—and all the other metro areas are able to hold that case number down, then it’s a very different picture, but you have to predict on the data you have, which is heavily skewed to New York and New Jersey.

Later in the press briefing, when Dr. Birx was asked if the New York and New Jersey infection patterns (Figure 3) were likely to occur in other states, she replied, “That’s the piece that we’re trying to prevent in New Orleans, in Detroit, in Chicago, and in Boston right now, and trying to make sure that each of those cities work more like California than the New York metro area.”

In drawing contrasts among states, Drs. Birx and Fauci implicitly acknowledged the important statistical principle that “data are not just numbers, they are numbers with a context” (Cobb and Moore, 1997, p. 801). In this case, they tried to convince the audience that it would be more desirable to create contextual circumstances across the United States that resembled those in California rather than those in New York. At one point, Dr. Birx tried to explain the differences in mitigation and timing across states, saying that officials in Washington state and California “really talked to their communities and decided to mitigate” a week or two in advance of New York and New Jersey. She believed this explained why the New York and New Jersey case graphs had large spikes (Figures 3 and 4) and Washington and California did not.

The connections between data and context Dr. Birx discussed led to mitigation measures in some states, but in other states, some governors quickly cast mitigation measures aside. Various political considerations likely influenced their choices. It is beyond the scope of this essay to review all of these considerations, but it seems likely that statistical reasoning also played a role. Historically, many enacted statistics curricula have suffered from lack of attention to forging connections between data and context (Jones and Tarr, 2010; Makar and Ben-Zvi, 2011); efforts to facilitate this type of reasoning in schools are relatively new (Pfannkuch, 2018). Those with this curricular knowledge, another aspect of SKT, can anticipate a need for a stronger attempt to prompt the audience to build statistical knowledge by “continual shuttling backwards and forwards between thinking in the context sphere and the statistical sphere” (Wild and Pfannkuch, 1999, p. 228). Engaging in this type of shuttling allows learners to make conjectures about why observed trends in data are happening and what they mean.

The spaghetti chart slides used during the press briefing (Figures 3 and 4) do provide starting points for reconciling data and context, as they disaggregated data by region. The main difficulty, however, is they do not readily provide information about the contextual dynamics of each region. Hyperlinking each spaghetti strand to a table and map with details about contextual dynamics for the region it represents may help. Each spaghetti strand could potentially be linked to tables containing information such as mitigation measures, timing of mitigation, types of mitigation, amount of testing, number of cases, number of deaths, maps showing where cases have been clustered, and any other information needed to understand the given region. The ability to link multiple types of representations, on a single screen, for seamless exploration, is another notable technology-based advance in statistics pedagogy over the past two decades (Mojica, Azmy, and Lee, 2019). Knowing of these linking abilities and their potential uses can be considered another aspect of knowledge of content and teaching within SKT. Putting an interactive representation of this nature online (as has been done with dynamic election maps) could make it readily accessible to viewers after the press briefing. Presenters at the press briefing could demonstrate how the display works, encourage others to explore further after the press conference, and make efforts to spread the representation via social media after the press briefing.

As the public examines statistics such as number of cases and number of deaths in a given region, learning supports to help them discern the affordances and limitations of each statistic would also be desirable. The activities of reading behind the data (Shaughnessy, 2007) and exploring limitations of statistics (Whitin, 2006) have also historically been neglected in many statistics curricula. Knowing this about the curriculum (an aspect of SKT) allows one to anticipate the need to remediate gaps in public knowledge. Relying on a single statistic, such as the number of cases documented, greatly weakens the conclusions one can draw from the data, yet it was a common tendency during the pandemic (Bronner, 2020). Considering complementary information such as number of deaths, hospitalizations, and amount of testing can help one draw more reliable conclusions. Using the press briefing to seed healthy skepticism about the amount of information any statistic on its own can provide and then encouraging online exploration of the earlier-recommended dynamic and linked representations may help the public appreciate important nuances of the situation.

3.4 SKT and Experimental Study Design
Near the conclusion of the press briefing, discussion turned toward vaccine development. A reporter asked, “How long does that normally take? Weeks? Months?” Dr. Fauci replied “at least months,” explaining, “the drugs that you want to show in a good randomized clinical trial, at very best, they’re going to take months.” The concept of clinical trials emerged again when conversation turned toward development of treatments for those who were already infected. A reporter asked President Trump, “Going back to hydroxychloroquine, how many clinical trial tests, numerically, would you like to see before you put a stamp of approval on it? Because it’s—there are clinical trials being—taking place around the world right now.” Dr. Fauci responded for the President, prompting the following exchange:

Reporter: Is there a number? How many cases would you like to see?

Dr. Fauci: Yeah. That is an FDA decision and it really depends on a variety of factors. What I would like to see: a clinical trial that has a comparison to something that is comparable to what it means without the drug. I mean, I keep saying it. I say it all the time and I’ll say it again: It’s a controlled trial that compares it to something meaningful. When that—

Reporter: Are there particular trials that you’re watching taking place around the world right now?

Dr. Fauci: Well, there are a number of trials going on, not only in the United States, but also in other parts of the world. You know, right now, it’s too early to make any determination, but I just want to get back to what I say all the time: The definitive way that you get an answer is by doing a randomized, controlled, clinical trial.

Reporter: Dr. Fauci, on social distancing. Or Mr. President—President Trump: You’re talking about the chloroquine? Is that what you’re talking about? In—specifically, per the last question?

Reporter: Yes. Hydroxychloroquine.

President Trump: Yeah. No, there are trials going on. But there are also trials going on—we’re trying them on people that are now sick. That’s a very important—that’s a very important trial, to me.

After this exchange, the conversation turned to other matters.

During the exchange above involving Dr. Fauci, news reporters, and President Trump, it was not clear that a shared understanding of the notion of “randomized clinical trial” existed. Reporters alluded to trials taking place around the world with those who were sick. At the time, these were generally observational rather than experimental studies, as indicated by Dr. Fauci’s remarks. The initial reporter question to start the conversation pertained to the number of trials conducted rather than the manner in which they were done. Dr. Fauci then attempted to steer the conversation back to randomized clinical trials. After Dr. Fauci made this statement, though, President Trump seemed to return to something close to the reporter’s original notion of trials, referring to those who were infected and receiving the medicine as a last resort. The entire exchange suggested that the parties involved may have been talking past one another when using the word trial. The knowledge of content and students aspect of SKT can help one anticipate these types of communication difficulties; words such as random and trial that have both well-established colloquial meanings as well as more precise statistical meanings can be particularly troublesome for learners (Kaplan, Fisher, and Rogness, 2010). Helping citizens and elected officials distinguish among these shades of meaning is particularly important when personal health and public policy decisions are at stake.

Explicit language supports can help individuals distinguish between everyday and technical meanings of words. Existing research has begun to shed light on the types of language supports that may be most effective. Kaplan, Rogness, and Fisher (2014) found that a visual analogy contrasting statistical and colloquial meanings of the word random helped improve learners’ understanding. They cautioned, however, that more research was needed on the potential widespread effectiveness of this type of intervention, recommending further research on how and why the changes they observed occurred. Pairing the word random with the phrase clinical trial would likely complicate the intervention further. However, once developed by further research, such interventions could become an important component of the knowledge of content and teaching aspect of SKT. The need for additional research on this aspect of SKT shows that this type of knowledge, just as medical knowledge, needs continuous development through empirical study. Although existing literature suggests aspects of SKT that would be beneficial to health care professionals, SKT is not a static construct ready for simple transmission to users. Both SKT and medicine are aspects of the knowledge base for health care professionals that need continuous empirical development.

4. Implications for the Statistical Education of Health Care Professionals
The examples of SKT discussed above are summarized in Table 1. The entries in Table 1 likely represent just a small fraction of the aspects of SKT that are important to health care professionals. From this handful of examples, however, one can begin to recognize that the SKT aspects discussed in this essay can be useful for health care professionals beyond the specific press conference and situation that have been described. Hence, in this section, the potential broader applicability of the SKT elements summarized in Table 1 will be briefly considered.

4.1 Knowledge of Content and Students for Health Care Professionals
The knowledge of content and students portion of Table 1 contains examples of common statistical learning issues related to the substance of the press briefing. The first challenge is to develop learners’ abilities to distinguish between deterministic and stochastic phenomena. In this essay, the issue was considered in relation to interpretation of statistical model predictions. The ability to distinguish between deterministic and stochastic phenomena, however, underlies many other medical issues facing the public. For example, people may believe that medical tests provide deterministic results, overlooking possibilities of false positives and false negatives; it is then surprising for them to learn that a test advertised to have 99% accuracy can produce false positives at high rates like 25% under some circumstances (Lyublinskaya, 2005). Also, headlines and images in drug advertisements have the potential to lead the public to deterministic conclusions about drug efficacy (Wilkes, Doblin, and Shapiro, 1992). Advertisements about one drug being more effective than another can exploit colloquial deterministic meanings of effectiveness rather than explaining the more tentative and qualified statistical conclusions drawn in comparative studies.

It is important for health care professionals to understand the nature, origin, and prevalence of difficulties the public may have interpreting what they read and hear about medicine in everyday life so they can anticipate the need to provide appropriate learning supports. The examples above are by no means exhaustive. They are merely intended to illustrate that the need for SKT related to common patterns of thinking about statistics extends beyond the press briefing considered earlier. The essay examples are also intended to encourage research activity that can more fully characterize the SKT that is needed to educate the public at-large to foster their well-being. Further study of health care professionals in the act of trying to help others understand statistical information could produce a comprehensive inventory of the SKT needed to foster public well-being, just as studies of interactions in statistics classrooms have led to characterizations of the SKT needed by teachers (e.g., Pfannkuch, 2006; Burgess, 2011).

4.2 Knowledge of Content and Teaching for Health Care Professionals
Knowing the statistical thinking tendencies that exist among the public in regard to health issues is important, but not sufficient. It is also important to have teaching strategies that foster sound understanding. As summarized in the second row of Table 1, recent developments in statistics education technology offer options for doing so. In this essay, it was conjectured that dynamic and linked representations would have enhanced the instruction attempted during the press conference. Technology also offers additional options for addressing the learning difficulties mentioned in the previous section. In particular, many platforms afford the ability to conduct simulations that demonstrate frequencies of random outcomes (Garfield and Ben-Zvi, 2008). Examining such frequencies can help users develop sounder intuition about issues such as occurrence of false positives (Lyublinskaya, 2005) and the likely range of conclusions that might be drawn when an experiment comparing two treatments is replicated many times (Chance, Wong, and Tintle, 2016). Although interpreting simulations has its own challenges (Case and Jacobbe, 2018), there is growing evidence that simulation-based approaches are more effective than traditional approaches to teaching inference (Chance, Wong, and Tintle, 2016). As research on SKT related to health issues becomes more prevalent, it would be wise to interrogate and continuously improve all of the capabilities that statistics education technology currently has to offer to support the development of knowledge of content and teaching.

Many attempts to provide technology-based learning supports for interpreting COVID-19 data and models did, in fact, emerge as the pandemic spread. For example, some websites used dynamic models that allowed for the alteration of inputs and outputs to help users see how the spread of a virus would change in response to different conditions (e.g., https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/world/corona-simulator/, https://www.nctm.org/Classroom-Resources/Illuminations/Interactives/Pandemics-How-Are-Viruses-Spread/). Others provided dashboards and continuous updates on data pertaining to the spread of the virus (e.g., https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/, https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html). No such tools, however, were featured during the press briefing considered in this essay. Statistical models and data were prominently featured during the briefing. However, the conduct of the press briefing, which was viewed by millions at a critical time in the spread of the pandemic, did not reflect a corresponding degree of attention to how individuals interpret models and data or contemporary learning supports to help the interpretation process. Given that a main goal of the press briefing was to use statistics to argue that government-created mitigation measures were necessary, a greater degree of attention to choosing appropriate teaching strategies would have been desirable. The need for SKT in this highly visible situation amplifies the need for health care professionals to have similar knowledge to support their private professional interactions with individuals as well; collectively, such smaller-scale interactions also have a large impact on overall public health.

4.3 Knowledge of Curriculum for Health Care Professionals
The press briefing reflections also amplify the need for knowledge of statistics curricula among health care professionals. People are not blank slates; rather, they bring past experiences to bear in any situation. Experiences with school statistics curricula influence their interpretation of messages health care professionals attempt to convey. At present, it is important for health care professionals to know that many statistics curricula currently suffer from lack of attention to reconciling data and context, reading behind the data, and understanding limitations of individual statistical measures. The impacts of these deficits on the ability of the public to understand press briefing remarks were discussed earlier. Beyond the press briefing, many media stories omit information or make errors when reporting the contextual details of medical research studies (Chang, 2015) or intentionally sensationalize them (Shuchman and Wilkes, 1997). The public often struggles to interpret and scrutinize media stories in a sound manner (Adams et al., 2017). Many current statistics curricula exacerbate the problem by not including opportunities for students to carefully interpret data in context. This makes it less likely that readers of media stories will probe the underlying contextual details of the research on which the stories are based. Knowing of such curriculum-induced challenges to helping individuals intelligently examine statistical claims is important for health care professionals charged with advising the public.

Of course, there are even more pressing matters than knowledge of curriculum deficits; it is important to work toward sounder statistics curriculum strategies. K-12 curriculum improvements in statistics and probability have been uneven over the past several decades. Once reserved mainly for post-secondary study, probability and statistics gained momentum as strands running through the entire K-12 curriculum near the end of the twentieth century with the release of Curriculum and Evaluation Standards for School Mathematics (National Council of Teachers of Mathematics, 1989) and Principles and Standards for School Mathematics (National Council of Teachers of Mathematics, 2000). More recently, however, Curriculum Focal Points (National Council of Teachers of Mathematics, 2006) and the Common Core State Standards (Common Core State Standards Initiative, 2010) removed most probability and statistics content from the elementary grades. Some countries that once engaged young children in studying intuitive ideas of probability have removed probability from their early grades curricula (Langrall, 2018). The erratic starts and stops in curriculum reform in statistics and probability have made it difficult to achieve meaningful, lasting progress to help all citizens develop sound statistical and probabilistic reasoning. The COVID-19 pandemic vividly illustrates the pressing need for widespread statistical literacy, lending urgency to efforts to improve K-12 statistics and probability curricula.

At present, health care professionals need to know the nature of prevailing statistics curricula so they can anticipate extant gaps in statistical knowledge they are likely to encounter. Ideally, such knowledge would not only help them carry out their traditional professional responsibilities, but also prompt them to become partners in efforts to improve existing statistics curricula. Such partnerships should aim to enhance the public’s statistical thinking abilities on a broad scale. Meaningful curriculum reform is a complex, gradual process, so efforts of this nature must be sustained over a long period of time to effect change. Recognizing the connections between the public’s statistical literacy and their overall health and well-being may help foster the perseverance needed to develop and build long-lasting partnerships for curricular reform and further SKT research.

5. Concluding Reflections
If one accepts the argument that SKT is an important aspect of the knowledge base for health care professionals, it is natural to ask how to include it in already overburdened medical school curricula. One possibility would be to purposefully develop SKT in already-required statistics courses. Models for teacher education provide strategies for addressing SKT and conventional statistics subject matter knowledge alongside one another in the same course (e.g., Groth, 2012; Green and Blankenship, 2013; Biehler, Frischemeier, and Podworny, 2018). One advantage of integrating SKT outcomes is that doing so provides opportunities to reflect on common statistical misunderstandings and how to remediate them. Potential (and practicing) health care professionals are not immune to such misunderstandings themselves. For example, Lang (2007) reported frequent errors in biomedical journals pertaining to interpretation and use of statistical significance, standard error, and standard deviation. Studying common statistical misunderstandings of others as part of required statistics coursework has the potential to make health care professionals more self-aware of the need to address such misunderstandings in their own thinking. Hence, in a carefully designed course, the study of SKT could actually enhance their subject matter knowledge rather than taking time away from its development.

Even with improved coursework, however, it should be acknowledged that work demands make it difficult for health care professionals to stay abreast of all emerging research on the teaching and learning of statistics. In regard to the press briefing considered in this essay, for example, the technology-based pedagogical tools recommended to enhance the briefing did not exist when the two doctors presenting were in medical school. In high-stakes efforts to educate the public, a team approach is needed. The examples in this essay suggest that having statistics education specialists on such teams is essential so that common statistical thinking patterns are taken into account and addressed in the most effective ways possible. If the public is not convinced that mitigation measures are needed on the basis of empirical evidence, the only teaching tool that remains is appeal to authority. Relying on appeal to authority alone is not only unsound pedagogically; in a democratic society it can, and did, cause systematic backlash against the recommended measures. As the so-called “pandemic playbooks” in various countries around the world are scrutinized and revised in the wake of COVID-19, democratic countries would be especially remiss to ignore the role of statistics education in their observed successes and failures during the pandemic.

Just as enhanced SKT can help improve medical education, recognizing it as necessary for medical education can help improve SKT research. To remain viable, both SKT and medicine require continually growing and evolving bodies of knowledge based on empirical data. Partnerships between statistics education researchers and medical researchers would be mutually beneficial. For example, as suggested earlier, statistics education researchers might analyze the clinical practice of doctors by using tools that have been developed to examine teachers’ SKT in conventional classroom settings (e.g., Pfannkuch, 2006; Burgess, 2011). As another example, technology-based teaching tools could be examined for their effectiveness in health care contexts and then refined in response to peoples’ thinking about them; such investigations could benefit from methods and tools developed for design-based research in statistics (Bakker and van Eerde, 2015) that allow researchers to develop and improve the tools in a bootstrapping fashion. This essay only scratches the surface in providing direction for partnerships between statistics education researchers and medical researchers. The conjectures offered herein provide potential starting points for such efforts, but many other focus areas are ripe for identification and empirical study.

In closing, it is useful to revisit Shulman’s (1987) original characterization of pedagogical content knowledge as the “special amalgam of content and pedagogy that is uniquely the province of teachers, their own special form of professional understanding” (p. 8). In light of the examples offered in this essay, one might question whether such knowledge should really be just “uniquely the province of teachers.” Or, if one holds to the original characterization, it must be acknowledged that health care professionals need to be considered statistics teachers in their own right. In any case, we must find ways to better prepare them to carry out their teaching functions and provide extra support as needed, especially in large-scale, high-stakes scenarios such as COVID-19. Improving society’s capacity to more effectively teach statistical thinking before and during situations where public health hangs in the balance is paramount.

ABSTRACT
Entrepreneurship is at the heart of new developments that often lead to the creation of new industries. This study examines the origins of the canning industry via the experiences of three of its earliest entrepreneurs: Edward Wright, William Numsen, and Thomas Kensett II. The narrative examines key aspects of the industry’s context including the growth in demand for preserved foods, the resources of the Chesapeake region, and the development of food preservation technology. Using the five characteristics of entrepreneurial processes, the importance of entrepreneurs in the development of the economic growth of Baltimore’s early canning industry is examined. Each founder exhibited entrepreneurial characteristics in different ways. One failed in his efforts; the other two succeeded in developing businesses that endured into the next century. The study reveals that using entrepreneurial processes does not guarantee success, and that there are various paths to success. An entrepreneurial multiplier effect was also evident in the growth of firms producing supplies and equipment for canners. Using an entrepreneurial lens offers a closer insight into the development of firms and their industries. Some remaining unanswered questions as well as avenues for future studies are discussed.

KEYWORDS: Canning industry, entrepreneurial processes, industry growth, Chesapeake region, Baltimore city, food preservation

This paper examines the impact of regulation-driven trade barriers on export entrepreneurship in a panel of 60 countries between 2006 and 2014. The paper finds robust evidence that unfavorable trade regulations significantly reduce export entry rate and export entry density (two critical measures of export entrepreneurship) by increasing the time and cost associated with documentary and customs compliance procedures. These findings support the hypothesis that less conducive business regulations are an important domestic supply constraint which impedes export entrepreneurship by increasing trade costs. In addition, the paper finds that the magnitude of the negative relationship between export entrepreneurship and regulation-driven trade barriers is significantly more pronounced in countries with poor governance quality. Two measures of governance quality (i.e., political stability and rule of law) are shown to be relatively more significant in aiding favorable trade regulations that promote export entrepreneurship. Furthermore, a reduction in regulation-driven trade barriers has a positive impact on net entry rate and survival rates of first-, second- and third-year exporters, and high-quality governance institutions significantly increase the magnitude of this positive relationship.

ABSTRACT Empathy with a rape victim was examined based on knowing a rape victim (not oneself), personal sexual victimization experience, and participant gender. Undergraduates (n = 531) at a midsize public university in the Northeast United States completed the Rape-Victim Empathy Scale, the Sexual Experiences Survey-Short Form Victimization, and questions regarding knowing a rape victim. Empathy scores were greater for those who reported knowing a rape victim than for those who did not. Women with personal sexual victimization experience reported greater empathy than men with personal sexual victimization experience and all nonvictims, but no differences emerged among female nonvictims and all men. Findings suggest that knowing a rape victim may provide some degree of vicarious experience with rape that helps individuals better understand a rape victim’s perspective, and factors influencing rape empathy among men and nonvictims needs more attention in future research. ABSTRACT
This paper examines the hitherto unexplored subject of nonstate rebels seeking the status of sole representatives. Why do nonstate armed groups seek the status of sole representatives?, What strategies do they employ to achieve the status of sole representatives?, Is the status merely symbolic, or does it fetch tangible benefits? These research questions are explored by treating Sri Lanka’s LTTE as a case study. Primary and secondary data formed the basis of the analysis. The LTTE used three strategies to achieve a hegemonic disposition within the Tamil community. They are: (1) elimination of rival groups, (2) incorporation of some groups, and (3) battlefield efficacy. The rebels used the claim of sole representation to ensure bilateral talks with the government, get the ban on it lifted, and control the proposed interim administrative structure. The strategy worked to a certain extent, but at least partially contributed to its downfall in 2009.

ABSTRACT
The retention of students is a challenge faced by many universities in countries where participation rates are high. Living learning communities (LLCs) have been adopted by college administrators to increase retention, even though evidence of their effectiveness is largely anecdotal. This paper uses propensity score matching to address selection bias and identify the causal effect of an LLC program on GPA and retention. Survival analysis (of the matched sample) is used to estimate retention over time. Results suggest that the LLC program has a positive and lasting effect on retention and a positive impact on GPA in the earlier college years.

ABSTRACTFor the past 100 years, the Supreme Court ruling in the case of Schenck v. United States, 249 U.S. 47, from 1919 has stood as a landmark case due to the Court’s creation of a “Clear and Present Danger” standard of freedom of speech. Through the vehicle of the Clear and Present Danger measure, the Court reconsidered that the degree of freedom for inflammatory rhetoric could be legally permissible until the point that realistic danger of harm or illegal action might occur. One century after this ruling, this paper examines the unprecedentedly divisive and uncivil public rhetoric of a US President, Donald J. Trump. Student evaluations of teaching are ubiquitous in higher education; however, most prior research has focused on the numeric ratings, with little systematic attention given to the qualitative comments. In this study, written comments were collected as part of the regular evaluation of a community health nursing course over four semesters. Taken as a whole, student comments were strikingly consistent and mostly negative. Students emphasized the authority of the textbook and framed the course as preparation for the National Council Licensure Examination (NCLEX). Instructor efforts to focus on critical analysis of social issues were met with confusion, suspicion, and resistance. Student comments were further analyzed in relation to 3 levels of discourse: the student/teacher level, the nursing-education level, and the social–historical level. For each level, the comments reveal problems, but not the ones suggested by a conventional reading of student evaluations. If students and teachers have conflicting expectations about goals and methods for learning, formal student evaluations may be less useful as a measure of teaching effectiveness. This study also raises troubling concerns about current practices in nursing pedagogy, particularly the emphasis on standardized testing and highly structured didactics, and the overlap between student evaluation systems and the technologies of neoliberalism.

Sprint interval training (SIT) refers to a group of sprint bouts separated by rest periods. SIT is a time-efficient strategy to improve aerobic performance similar to moderate intensity continuous training (MICT). There has been a relative absence of studies on neuromuscular adaptations of SIT.
PURPOSE: To compare the effects of stationary air biking, utilizing high-volume MICT and low-volume SIT (i.e., ultrashort-SIT [US], short-SIT [SS]) on neuromuscular system.
METHODS: Thirty recreationally active females were randomly assigned to MICT (n = 10), US (n = 10), and SS (n = 10) groups. The intervention consisted of 3 d/wk for 4 wks. MICT was performed by 30 min of cycling at 75% of maximal heart rate reserve, while SIT (i.e., US, SS) consisted of 3 sets of 8 intervals at maximal effort intensity. SS and US were performed with 20s:10s and 10s:5s work-to-rest ratios and provided with 5- and 2.5-min recovery periods between sets, respectively. Muscle cross-sectional area (mCSA) and echo intensity (EI) of rectus femoris (RF) and vastus lateralis (VL) were measured by ultrasound system. Isometric strength testing protocol consisted of 3 maximal voluntary isometric contractions (MVIC). During each contraction, surface electromyography (sEMG) and torque signals were recorded to assess sEMG amplitude (RMS) of RF and VL as well as peak torque (PT). All variables were measured before and after intervention and were analyzed with 2-way mixed factorial ANOVAs. Moreover, average total work (TW) during 12 sessions was recorded and analyzed with one-way ANOVA.
RESULTS: There were significant (p < 0.05) differences in TW (MICT: 142.7 ± 31.5 cal., US: 52.6 ± 10.0 cal., SS: 92.3 ± 7.8 cal.) between groups. All groups significantly (p < 0.05) improved mCSA of RF (MICT: 9.0 ± 1.0 to 9.5 ± 1.1 cm2, US: 9.9 ± 3.5 to 10.6 ± 3.6 cm2, SS: 9.0 ± 1.9 to 9.7 ± 1.5 cm2) and VL (MICT: 20.0 ± 2.3 to 20.6 ± 2.1 cm2, US: 20.8 ± 5.1 to 22.5 ± 5.2 cm2, SS: 19.6 ± 2.6 to 21.4 ± 3.8 cm2). No significant (p > 0.05) differences observed in EI values as well as RMS and PT during MVIC.
CONCLUSION: Despite no significant improvements in neural activation and isometric strength, all groups similarly improved muscular morphology of RF and VL by performing SIT on a stationary air bike. These findings suggest that SIT can elicit muscular morphological adaptations with a shorter time commitment.
